detail.title: Fact-Checking at a Crossroads: Challenges, Alternatives, and Policy Interventions
detail.abstract: Independent fact-checking organisations play a crucial role in combating misinformation. Social media platforms, such as Meta and X, have scaled back their collaboration with professional fact-checking organisations, leading to financial strain on the industry and increased risks of misinformation. Alternative approaches, such as crowdsourced or AI-driven fact-checking, face significant limitations when used in isolation from professional fact-checkers. They often lack the investigative rigour, critical thinking, and independence that characterise professional fact-checking. A hybrid approach that combines professional and non-professional approaches may be more effective for combating misinformation. Given ongoing challenges, public intervention may be necessary to support the sustainability of fact-checking initiatives and address the challenges posed by misinformation.

detail.title: Inferring Duty under the "Stop Campus Hazing Act": National Fraternity and Sorority Liability
detail.abstract: Scores of states have enacted laws that prohibit hazing.  However, the regulations, penalties, and requirements vary from state to state.  On December 23, 2024, President Joe Biden signed the Stop Campus Hazing Act (SCHA) into law, making it the first federal law to create anti-hazing requirements for institutions of higher education outside of military academies.  The federal SCHA was a bipartisan statute aimed at combating hazing on college campuses.  The SCHA amended Section 485(f) of the Higher Education Act of 1965, otherwise known as the “Jeanne Clery Disclosure of Campus Security Policy and Campus Crime Statistics Act” (Clery Act).  The SCHA requires that higher education institutions that participate in Title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965 programs to collect, report, and publicly disclose hazing-related incidents.  The SCHA requires that institutions create a hazing policy statement that reflects its anti-hazing policies on or before June 23, 2025.  Pursuant to the SCHA, the hazing policy statement must include (1) a “statement of current policies relating to hazing (as defined by the institution)”; (2) the process by which someone may report an incident of alleged hazing; (3) an overview of the institution’s procedure for investigating a claim of hazing; and (4) all applicable local, state, and tribal laws.  In conjunction with the policy statement, campuses must also report information that relates to the institutions’ campus-wide hazing education and prevention programming.  As such, it requires them to implement hazing prevention and awareness programs.  The SCHA specifies that any such program implemented by an institution must be “research-informed” and available “campus-wide” to effectively reach students, staff, and faculty.  As such, if an institution does not have a hazing prevention and awareness program in place, or such program does not comply with the SCHA’s requirements, the policy must be in compliance on or before June 23, 2025. The SCHA does not apply to organizations outside of colleges and universities. However, the statute suggests that education and training are critical components of hazing prevention. In doing so, it raises the specter, in litigation, that other organizations that have a long history of hazing issues—e.g., collegiate fraternities and sororities—must similarly employ “research-informed” hazing prevention methods. Section I explores how liability is raised and adjudicated with respect to victims, chapter members, and chapters in hazing litigation. Section II explores how liability is raised and adjudicated with respect to fraternity and sorority national organizations. Section III hazing liability in the context of the tort of negligence and how education and training factor here. Section IV explores the types of information that fraternity and sorority national organizations should teach to better equip  members and prospective members with understanding hazing and to promote hazing prevention.

detail.title: Does Inventory Turnover Matter under Competitive Pressure? Evidence from U.S. Import Tariff Reductions
detail.abstract: This paper examines how inventory turnover, a key indicator of operational flexibility, shapes firms' strategic responses to intensified product market competition. Leveraging a comprehensive panel of U.S. manufacturing firms from 1978 to 2023, we exploit plausibly exogenous industry-level tariff reductions to assess how firms with high inventory turnover (HIT) versus low inventory turnover (LIT) are differentially affected by, and respond to, heightened competitive pressure. We find that LIT firms experience significant declines in sales growth, especially to non-major customers, and in stock returns following tariff reductions, whereas HIT firms are largely insulated from these negative effects and are shown to raise R&D spending. Our findings suggest that HIT firms mitigate competitive shocks by retaining customers, especially those non-major ones, through relationship-specific investments. Additional tests rule out alternative explanations related to trade credit management, financing constraints, and labor productivity. Overall, the findings highlight the strategic value of inventory turnover as a key operational capability that enhances firms' resilience to intensified market competition.

detail.title: Do Diaspora Remittances Reduce Protest Frequency in Fragile Democracies? A Novel Non-Linear Analysis with Threshold Effects
detail.abstract: This study uncovers a novel non-linear relationship between diaspora remittances and political protests in fragile democracies, using comprehensive data from 47 countries (2000-2023). Below a critical threshold of 8.2% of GDP, remittances reduce protests by providing economic stability; above it, they increase protests by enabling political independence. For example, in Nigeria (4.9% of GDP), a 10% remittance increase could reduce its 203 yearly protests by about 2 events, while in Lebanon (28.4% of GDP), the same increase could add protests, reflecting heightened mobilization capacity. Using instrumental variables with oil price shocks, the analysis challenges linear assumptions about remittances' political effects and offers actionable insights for diaspora engagement in high-dependence states like Honduras, El Salvador, and Nepal, where traditional stabilization policies may backfire.

detail.abstract: No sport is as closely tied to the business world as golf, which has long served as a powerful networking tool. Historically the game has been dominated by male players, reinforcing the perception of golf as an “old boys club,” where access to influential networks is disproportionally available to men. This exclusivity creates a double-barreled impact, as it perpetuates systemic inequities that restrict women’s full participation in both leisure and professional settings. With only 26% of golfers identifying as women, the sport remains a male-dominated space amplifying the challenges of tokenism, statistical discrimination, and social closure.  This imbalance also persists in the business world, where women hold only 29% of C-Suite positions and where 90% of CEOs golf. This study explores the interconnected structural, cultural, and historical barriers that contribute to the “grass ceiling,” by applying the frameworks of tokenism, statistical discrimination, and social closure.  Findings from a survey of 323 business professionals reveal that women are more likely to encounter discrimination and perceive golf as less accessible than men. Moreover, the impact of tokenism heightens visibility pressures on women golfers, statistical discrimination reinforces gendered stereotypes, and social closure mechanisms maintain institutional barriers to access. Men, on the other hand, report higher satisfaction and greater perceived benefits from golf. To address these inequities, this study provides recommendations for the golf industry and business leaders to address structural barriers and modernize golf’s cultural narratives. By tackling these barriers, golf can move beyond its exclusionary past and become a more inclusive, equitable, environment in both leisure and professional settings.

detail.abstract: Using novel manually collected financial technology (FinTech) patent application data, we document that FinTech development significantly reduces the information content of financial reporting, as evidenced by lower stock market reactions to corporate earnings announcements. Mechanism analysis indicates that the incremental and timely information generated by FinTech can effectively substitute for financial disclosures. This is especially pronounced in cases of limited corporate disclosures or high trading decision uncertainty. We exclude the alternative explanation that changes in corporate financial reporting quality drive these effects. Results suggest that FinTech improves financial information acquisition and processing and, in turn, the price informativeness in financial markets.

detail.abstract: Brands increasingly sponsor influencers to produce visual content. Unlike conventional advertising, influencers have creative autonomy in content creation. This means that despite sponsorship agreements, influencers often prioritize their personal influencer salience (i.e., visibility) in visual content to preserve genuine connections with their community, at the expense of brand salience and the alignment of the content with the brand's visual communication style. To overcome this tension between brands and influencers, this research assesses the potential of visual generative AI (GenAI) to create visual brand content for sponsored posts. The authors develop a new visual GenAI workflow that is trained on influencer-, brand-, and social media visual content and compare the visual content it generates to conventional influencer content. Across four studies, this research shows that GenAI content with low-touch human input can improve the visual balance between brands and influencers, while maintaining perceived alignment with influencer and brand communication styles as well as influencer authenticity. The research also finds that sponsored collaborations involving GenAI are acceptable to influencers as well as to consumers when AI content creation is disclosed. Collectively, these findings underpin fundamental shifts in how sponsored influencer content is going to be created in the very near future.

detail.abstract: Through a pre-registered, randomized controlled field experiment, we demonstrate that a tailored generative artificial intelligence (AI) as a solution can significantly improve outcomes in an online weight loss program. Our results indicate increases in the number of participants who successfully were no longer obese, as well as a total reduction in body mass index (BMI) and enhanced participation rates. This suggests that tailored generative AI represents a cost-effective alternative to traditional weight loss interventions. Though personalization of messaging to encourage weight loss through AI was effective, the attempt to harness this personalization to build a community of the kind that has traditionally supported weight loss goals was less effective. This suggests that using AI to encourage the kind of personalization that can underpin a community may backfire, and at least in the weight-loss context, it is more effective to use generative AI for personalizing individual experiences rather than pursuing large-scale ecosystem development.

detail.abstract: Objectives: The research examines the impact of neurocognitive training in helping to reduce impulse buying tendencies (IBT) in young adults (ages 18 to 25). Impulse buying may be triggered by cognitive and emotional triggers and is typically characterised by spontaneous and unplanned purchases. Neurocognitive training enhances cognitive and executive function like impulse control, working memory, and attention regulation and was used as an intervention as a way to reduce such behaviours. Methods: A sample of 120 participants (60 males and 60 females) completed pre-and post-intervention assessments using standardized measures of IBT. Results: Paired sample t-tests demonstrated a statistically significant reduction in scores for males (t = 13.09, p < .001) and females (t = 11.12, p < .001) with large effect sizes (Cohen's d = 1.32 for males and d = 1.41 for females). The intervention showed a 100.0% improvement rate, and both males (19.0%) and females (19.3%) showed clinically meaningful reductions in IBT. An independent samples t-test indicated that there was no significant difference between the males and females in the effectiveness of training (t = 1.42, p > .05). Conclusion: These figures indicate that neurocognitive exercise is a very effective, and the penis is neutral, intervention to reduce the behavior of buying impulses between young adults. Although these findings must be pushed and repeated, they will benefit the consumer initiatives and programs that teach economic self-regulation techniques.

title: Unraveling the Dynamics of Luxury and Sustainable Fashion: A Systematic Review within the Gulf Region Context

detail.title: Unraveling the Dynamics of Luxury and Sustainable Fashion: A Systematic Review within the Gulf Region Context
detail.abstract: Luxury fashion represents a significant and fast-growing segment of the consumer market in the Gulf region, with projections estimating its value to reach approximately USD 3.55 billion by 2025. Meanwhile, the integration of sustainable practices is being increasingly contemplated by luxury brands. However, integrating sustainability into the luxury fashion narrative within this region presents unique cultural and market-specific challenges. The reason for choosing this topic is based on the gap revealed in the research, which showed a lack of a comprehensive review of sustainable luxury in the Gulf region compared to other geographies like Europe. This systematic review seeks to critically examine the intersection between sustainability and luxury fashion consumption in the Gulf region by analyzing academic literature from the last 25 years. Specifically, it aims to identify consumer attitudes, examine the barriers to sustainability integration, and assess the extent to which global sustainability trends resonate within this unique cultural and economic context. Existing studies have primarily focused on four countries-the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Qatar, and Kuwait-highlighting the regional nature of this discourse. Employing the PRISMA methodology, this review analyzes academic literature published from 2000 to 2025. Sources were selected through comprehensive searches in major scholarly databases, including Elsevier ScienceDirect, Google Scholar, Web of Science, and Scopus. The review revealed that, despite a burgeoning global consciousness regarding sustainability, particularly among Generation Z and Millennials, there persists a discernible gap between consumer awareness and actual purchasing practices within the Gulf region. Furthermore, the concept of luxury is profoundly entrenched within the cultural fabric, accompanied by a limited understanding of sustainability challenges. Notable obstacles also exist in the adoption of circular economy principles within this area.

detail.title: When Patients Pay to Say "Thanks": Do Small Monetary Gifts Reflect the Quality of Physician Services in Online Healthcare?
detail.abstract: Online healthcare platforms worldwide are increasingly introducing an innovative feedback method that allows patients to express satisfaction through small monetary gifts to physicians, a practice already prevalent in China. Platform managers face a strategic decision regarding these gifts: Some have embraced them as indicators of physician service quality to guide patients in physician selection, while others have hesitated due to uncertainty about whether patients offer gifts to reward services already received or to strategically secure future preferential care. Hence, platform managers require evidencebased guidance on implementing, regulating, or prohibiting this practice. However, fundamental questions about this emerging feedback method remain unexplored: Does monetary feedback reflect service quality received, and how does it compare to traditional written feedback in capturing service quality? Our study addresses these critical gaps by examining how physician service quality influences patient monetary feedback using patient-physician interaction data from a leading online healthcare platform. We analyze three dimensions of service quality: responsiveness, socio-emotional support, and informational support. Our analysis reveals several findings with important implications for information systems research and practice. First, while industry experts question monetary feedback as a quality measure, we find that patients give gifts based on the physician's responsiveness they have already experienced. This confirms that monetary feedback serves as a reliable quality indicator. Second, contrary to conventional wisdom that emphasizes socio-emotional and informational support in online healthcare, we find that neither dimension significantly influences patient gift-giving behavior. Third, while platforms have universally adopted written feedback based on validity assumptions, we find that written feedback fails to reflect any of the three service quality dimensions we examined. Monetary feedback, in contrast, captures quality aspects that written feedback misses entirely. Finally, while the industry focuses heavily on minimizing wait times because it assumes patients prefer quick responses, our analysis reveals a deeper mechanism that challenges this assumption. Specifically, patients value responsiveness not because they prefer faster service, but because responsiveness reflects physicians' commitment to their care. These findings would assist healthcare platforms in designing and implementing feedback methods, patients in examining reliable indicators of physician quality, and policymakers in regulating monetary feedback.

title: Inevitable Errors: Defamation by Hallucination in AI Reasoning Models (forthcoming in the Journal of Free Speech Law 2025)

detail.abstract: Over the last millennium, defamation law has adapted to many new information technologies, including the printing press, the telegraph, and the internet. Now, defamation law must adapt to the challenges presented by generative artificial intelligence, and specifically the propensity of Large Language Models to produce defamatory hallucinations. In this article, we unite the lessons of legal history with cutting-edge computer science research in developing a legal framework for addressing defamatory hallucinations produced by AI reasoning models. This article breaks new ground by recognizing both the inevitability and even desirability (in some instances) of AI hallucinations. We argue that defamation law must carve out “breathing space” for hallucinations, just as it treats certain human failings as “inevitable errors” to achieve sound communications policy. We further contend that LLM producers should be subject to a duty to warn users of the prevalence and risk of hallucinations as well as a duty to keep search records for a limited time to assist plaintiffs in proving reputational harm. Once AI producers comply with these obligations, the common law should treat them as information distributors. Users who negligently spread hallucinated and defamatory falsehoods should be treated like incompetent or unscrupulous journalists passing along defamation from an unreliable source.

title: A Fourfold Pathogen Reference Ontology Suite

detail.title: A Fourfold Pathogen Reference Ontology Suite
detail.abstract: Background Infectious diseases remain a critical global health challenge, and the integration of standardized ontologies plays a vital role in managing related data. The Infectious Disease Ontology (IDO) and its extensions, such as the Coronavirus Infectious Disease Ontology (CIDO), are essential for organizing and disseminating information related to infectious diseases. The COVID-19 pandemic highlighted the need for updating IDO and its virus-specific extensions. There is an additional need to update IDO extensions specific to bacteria, fungus, and parasite infectious diseases. Methods The "hub-and-spoke" methodology is adopted to generate pathogen-specific extensions of IDO: Virus Infectious Disease Ontology (VIDO), Bacteria Infectious Disease Ontology (BIDO), Mycosis Infectious Disease Ontology (MIDO), and Parasite Infectious Disease Ontology (PIDO). Results IDO is introduced before reporting on the scopes, major classes and relations, applications and extensions of IDO to VIDO, BIDO, MIDO, and PIDO. Conclusions The creation of pathogen-specific reference ontologies advances modularization and reusability of infectious disease ontologies within the IDO ecosystem. Future work will focus on further refining these ontologies, creating new extensions, and developing application ontologies based on them, in line with ongoing efforts to standardize biological and biomedical terminologies for improved data sharing, quality, and analysis.

detail.abstract: Philippines has consistently ranked near the bottom in international tests such as TIMSS and PISA. This raises a question about where did our education system go wrong? Using the Guided AI Content Analysis (GAICA), inspired by the Guided Thematic Analysis (GAITA) model of Nguyen-Trung (2025), the GAICA prompt strategy, and the incorporation of the Berelson-style matrix, this study aims to map the 43 Grade 9 Science Competencies vis-à-vis the three PISA 2022 framework competencies. Findings reveal a disparity in the distribution of the competencies when categorized under the PISA framework. A staggering 31 of the 43 of the Science 9 competencies rely heavily on SC1 or "conceptual understanding", suggesting a curricular gap in skills related to inquirybased science and data interpretation. Therefore, it is recommended that greater emphasis should be placed in SC2 and SC3 competencies. he Department of Education should also review the alignment of the Science curriculum with international benchmarks like PISA and provide teachers with necessary tools and training on data analysis, data interpretation, and science-based inquiry to improve the quality of teaching and learning.

detail.abstract: This conceptual working paper examines the role of hospitality education in shaping sustainable leadership for a climate-resilient service industry. Amid rising environmental risks and shifting guest expectations, hospitality schools are uniquely positioned to embed sustainability into the managerial mindset. The paper proposes a pedagogical model that integrates experiential learning, sustainability science, and systems thinking into hospitality curricula. It also analyzes case examples from European institutions to illustrate how future hospitality leaders can be trained to balance profitability, environmental stewardship, and social responsibility. The goal is to offer a strategic academic framework for transforming hospitality education into a lever for long-term sustainability in the sector.

title: Beyond the Silicon Shield: TSMC, Geopolitical Turbulence, and the Institutional Politics of Global Tech Power
affiliations: University of South Carolina - Darla Moore School of Business

detail.title: Beyond the Silicon Shield: TSMC, Geopolitical Turbulence, and the Institutional Politics of Global Tech Power
detail.abstract: Semiconductors have become central to geopolitical rivalry and national strategy. This article examines Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) as a paradigmatic case of institutional transformation in strategic industries. More than a technological leader, TSMC has emerged as an institutional mediator-navigating overlapping policy regimes, supply chain fragmentation, and diverging state agendas. Drawing on TSMC's global expansion, especially its fabs in Arizona and Kumamoto, I show how firms are increasingly expected to perform quasi-sovereign functions: ensuring supply continuity, managing regulatory tensions, and absorbing geopolitical risk. I argue that prevailing discourses of "decoupling" and "reshoring" misdiagnose the problem, treating physical relocation as a proxy for strategic autonomy. Instead, I theorize institutional absorptive capacity as the foundation of long-term sovereignty: the ability of firms and states to learn, adapt, and coordinate across volatile environments. This requires shifting policy focus from industrial control to institutional designinvesting in learning systems, governance capacity, and trust-based cooperation. TSMC's trajectory thus signals a broader reconfiguration of state-firm boundaries and the emergence of a multipolar, narrative-driven political economy. The article concludes by outlining future research on cross-border institutional agency, strategic narrative construction, and techno-industrial governance beyond the U.S.-China binary.

detail.title: Conscientious Objection and Human Rights, a Systematic Analysis
detail.abstract: The right to conscientious objection is increasingly invoked, whether it is the conscience clause of doctors, the refusal of vaccination or any other practice that clashes with the convictions of some. How can respect for these beliefs, guaranteed by freedom of conscience and religion, be reconciled with respect for the law, the guarantor of social order? How legitimate is it to punish someone for refusing to take part in an action inconsistent with his moral or religious beliefs? What are the state's obligations faced with such objections? Why do conscience and the law increasingly clash in contemporary society? What are the relationships between law, morals and religion? These are the main questions that this book answers, by drawing on the philosophy of law, the history of law and human rights. It has been written in order to help understand conscientious objection and identify the correct criteria for assessing it.

detail.title: Diverse Approaches to Meaning-Making at the End of Life
detail.abstract: This essay explores interdisciplinary approaches to meaning-making at the end of life, building on existing existentially-oriented therapies such as Dignity Therapy and Meaning-Centered Psychotherapy. Drawing from psychology, gerontology, nursing, and pastoral care, the authors examine narrative-based techniques—life review, reminiscence therapy, ethical wills, and narrative therapy—as tools to enhance self-integration and self-transcendence among terminally ill individuals and healthy elders. These approaches, rooted in narrative theory and existential psychology, aim to support patients in achieving emotional well-being, spiritual peace, and a coherent sense of identity during their final life stages.

title: Selling More without Wasting Food: Can Online Restaurants Use Spending Threshold Discounts?
affiliations: The University of Hong Kong - Faculty of Business and Economics, Faculty of Business, Lingnan University and The University of Hong Kong

detail.title: Selling More without Wasting Food: Can Online Restaurants Use Spending Threshold Discounts?
detail.abstract: Spending Threshold Discounts (STDs)---offering discounts or free delivery for orders with total spending above a set amount---are widely used by restaurants on delivery platforms to boost sales. However, they risk increasing food waste if customers add items solely to qualify. We analyze this tension with an economic model wherein a monopolistic online restaurant sells to two groups of rational customers (budget-conscious college students and affluent professionals, both with varying inherent demand) when there is a single threshold. Surprisingly, we find that profit improvement through the STD and waste reduction may not conflict, because the STD affects the restaurant profit through three channels: 1) Order size expansions: Buyers (i.e., customers that make purchases) whose basket values with inherent demand are just below the threshold add items, but their added values are often less than the discount value, causing profit loss and unnecessary consumption or waste; 2) Buyer base expansions: Customers deterred by delivery fees may buy if a low threshold enables the discount with minimal added values; 3) Profit margin enhancements: The threshold creates a sudden drop in effective average price, enabling restaurants to raise marginal food prices. Therefore, under certain conditions, increased customer aversion to waste can boost profits by curbing inefficient order size expansions without affecting the other two channels. Besides, regulators can achieve a rare triple win---reducing waste, increasing welfare, and maintaining restaurant profits---by capping platform fees. Overall, smarter pricing, consumer awareness, and balanced regulation can harmonize profitability with sustainability in delivery markets.

title: Physics-aware Truck and Drone Delivery Planning Using Optimization & Machine Learning
affiliations: Dartmouth College - Thayer School of Engineering, Brandenburg University of Technology Cottbus-Senftenberg and Thayer School of Engineering, Dartmouth College

detail.title: Physics-aware Truck and Drone Delivery Planning Using Optimization & Machine Learning
detail.abstract: Combining an energy-efficient drone with a high-capacity truck for last-mile package delivery can benefit operators and customers by reducing delivery times and environmental impact. However, directly integrating drone flight dynamics into the combinatorially hard truck route planning problem is challenging. Simplified models that ignore drone flight physics can lead to suboptimal delivery plans. We propose an integrated formulation for the joint problem of truck route and drone trajectory planning and a new end-to-end solution approach that combines optimization and machine learning to generate high-quality solutions in practical online runtimes. Our solution method trains neural network predictors based on offline solutions to the drone trajectory optimization problem instances to approximate drone flight times, and uses these approximations to optimize the overall truck-and-drone delivery plan by augmenting an existing order-first-split-second heuristic. Our method explicitly incorporates key kinematics and energy equations in drone trajectory optimization, and thereby outperforms state-of-the-art benchmarks that ignore drone flight physics. Extensive experimentation using synthetic datasets and real-world case studies shows that the integration of drone trajectories into package delivery planning substantially improves system performance in terms of tour duration and drone energy consumption. Our modeling and computational framework can help delivery planners achieve annual savings worth millions of dollars while also benefiting the environment.

title: Revenue Management under Aggregate and Disaggregate Quality Rating Systems
affiliations: Miami University - Farmer School of Business, University of Miami - Department of Management and University of British Columbia

detail.title: Revenue Management under Aggregate and Disaggregate Quality Rating Systems
detail.abstract: Problem Definition: Online platforms increasingly rely on customer rating systems to reduce quality uncertainty and assist consumer choice. This paper investigates how optimal pricing and platform profitability are affected by the design of such systems—specifically, whether a platform displays one score across multiple products (aggregate system) or individual scores for each product (disaggregate system). Methodology/Results: We develop an analytical model where a set of substitutable products are sold through an online platform, and consumer demand is governed by the multinomial logit (MNL) framework. Ratings influence product attractiveness and market share, which in turn shapes future ratings. We compare aggregate and disaggregate rating systems across three pricing scenarios: exogenous prices, centralized pricing, and decentralized pricing. Our analysis reveals that rating design significantly alters equilibrium pricing strategies: the aggregate system yields differentiated markups across products, while the disaggregate system leads to uniform margins. Surprisingly, under centralized pricing, both systems generate identical total profit for the platform despite these contrasting price structures. This result highlights a novel form of strategic equivalence shaped by rating-based externalities. Under decentralized pricing, rating design continues to shape equilibrium outcomes, though the implications become more nuanced. Managerial Implications: Our findings offer new insights into the interplay between information design and pricing strategy in multi-product environments. Platform operators can use these insights to design rating systems that balance transparency, competitive positioning, and profitability. Even when transparency affects individual product performance, the platform may still achieve equivalent profitability through strategic price adjustments, depending on its control over pricing.

title: Going Public, Going Inclusive: Diversity Messaging in Job Postings

detail.title: Going Public, Going Inclusive: Diversity Messaging in Job Postings
detail.abstract: Significant organizational events, such as initial public offerings (IPOs), can trigger strategic changes within organizations. The transition from private to public arena through IPO significantly shifts firms’ visibility and strategic choices, increasing normative and growth pressures firms face. As such, firms can change their messaging in the labor market as a strategic tool in response to the new environment. This study focuses on changes in firms’ diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) messaging in job postings post-IPO by differentiating standardized diversity statements from tailored inclusive language. Text analysis of online job postings reveals no significant change in diversity statements but a notable increase in the discussion of inclusive work climate post-IPO. The positive effect is more pronounced among firms with substantial growth pressures and hiring demand. The study demonstrates that firms’ diversity claims in job postings are driven more by changes in their strategic labor market objectives than by shifts in the normative environment.

detail.abstract: The rapid development of digital technology has brought significant changes across various economic sectors, including Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs). The use of digital platforms such as e-commerce, social media, and digital payment applications has become a key factor in enhancing the competitiveness and growth of MSMEs. This article aims to analyze how the optimization of digital platforms can empower MSMEs by improving operational efficiency, expanding market reach, and increasing profitability. Using a literature review method and secondary data analysis, this study finds that strategic utilization of digital platforms can enhance business visibility, reduce operational costs, and open broader collaboration opportunities. However, low digital literacy and limited access to technology remain major challenges. Therefore, collaborative efforts from various stakeholders-including the government, digital platforms, and MSME actors-are essential to promote equitable adoption of digital technologies.

title: The Case for Mandating Tamper-Proof Watermarks on AI-Generated Media
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: The Case for Mandating Tamper-Proof Watermarks on AI-Generated Media
detail.abstract: As generative AI technologies proliferate, society faces a mounting challenge: how to maintain public trust in what we see, hear, and share. Tools that generate synthetic images, videos, and voices are now widely available, yet there is no universal requirement to mark such content as artificial. This paper argues for a mandatory, tamper-resistant watermarking system for all AI-generated media. It draws on existing industry standards, evaluates the technical viability of both visible and invisible watermarking, and identifies gaps in voluntary adoption. The paper contends that without enforceable labeling, the growing presence of synthetic media will erode democratic discourse, compromise digital forensics, and create systemic vulnerabilities in journalism, governance, and civil society. The proposed policy framework combines cryptographic provenance, standardized labeling, and multi-stakeholder oversight. It is designed to balance innovation with transparency, and to restore a baseline of trust in the information ecosystem.

title: Interactive, Grouped and Non-separable Fixed Effects: A Practitioner's Guide to the New Panel Data Econometrics

detail.title: Interactive, Grouped and Non-separable Fixed Effects: A Practitioner's Guide to the New Panel Data Econometrics
detail.abstract: The past 20 years have brought fundamental advances in modeling unobserved heterogeneity in panel data. Interactive Fixed Effects (IFE) proved to be a foundational framework, generalizing the standard one-way and two-way fixed effects models by allowing the unitspecific unobserved heterogeneity to be interacted with unobserved time-varying common factors, allowing for more general forms of omitted variables. The IFE framework laid the theoretical foundations for other forms of heterogeneity, such as grouped fixed effects (GFE) and non-separable two-way fixed effects (NSTW). The existence of IFE, GFE or NSTW has significant implications for identification, estimation, and inference, leading to the development of many new estimators for panel data models. This paper provides an accessible review of the new estimation methods and their associated diagnostic tests, and offers a guide to empirical practice. In two separate empirical investigations we demonstrate that there is empirical support for the new forms of fixed effects and that the results can differ significantly from those obtained using traditional fixed effects estimators.

title: An analytical heterogeneous agent macro model of concentration, markups, and falling labour shares
affiliations: University of Leeds, University of the West of England (UWE) and University of Geneva

detail.title: An analytical heterogeneous agent macro model of concentration, markups, and falling labour shares
detail.abstract: This paper presents a small-scale analytical heterogeneous agent model (HAM) to explore firm concentration dynamics and the aggregate effects on distribution and growth. It contributes to recent work on tractable macroeconomic agent-based models (ABMs) by comparing two versions of the model: an ABM with bilateral firm-customer matching, and a simplified HAM without direct agent interaction. The HAM replicates key ABM results while allowing for analytical solutions. The model captures how pricing, investment, and market concentration evolve at the micro level and affect macro-level outcomes. Firms differ in capital size and market share. Larger firms benefit from lower unit costs due to economies of scale, gain larger market shares, and charge higher markups. At the same time, customers seek lower prices, creating competitive pressure. These mechanisms drive endogenous changes in the firm size distribution. More profitable firms temporarily grow faster, leading to concentration of capital, market shares, and markups. These dynamics lead to right-skewed distributions, producing a divergence between the average profit share across firms and the aggregate profit share, which is driven up by the biggest firms. The fall in the labour share reduces consumption and slows down growth. Despite its simplicity, the model captures key empirical patterns related to superstar firms and declining labour shares.

detail.abstract: Because reforming ineffective law enforcement institutions is a formidable challenge, policymakers in violent societies often create new policing squads to reduce crime, curb abuses, and enhance legitimacy. We study the Rondas e Ações Intensivas e Ostensivas (RAIO) in Ceará, Brazil, a militarized, motorcycle-based police squad. Using difference-in-differences and regression discontinuity designs, we find that RAIO dramatically reduced homicides and property crimes, likely through deterrence rather than incapacitation, as arrests also declined. A citizen survey with 2,000 respondents and embedded experiments shows that RAIO is perceived as more effective, less corrupt, and less abusive than other forces. We demonstrate that RAIO's success did not increase human rights abuses, provided substantial social benefits relative to operational costs, and helped the incumbent governor electorally. We discuss the implications of our findings for institutional reform and public safety.

detail.abstract: With the rise of digital banking and the increasing demand for scalable, high-performance systems, traditional architectures often struggle to keep up with fluctuating workloads and complex banking processes. Serverless computing, an emerging paradigm, offers a novel solution by allowing developers to focus solely on application logic without worrying about the underlying infrastructure. This paper explores the application of serverless frameworks in building scalable backends for banking applications. We investigate the working principles of serverless architectures, highlighting their advantages in terms of cost-efficiency, scalability, and flexibility. Through a detailed analysis of current serverless platforms such as AWS Lambda, Google Cloud Functions, and Azure Functions, we examine how they can be leveraged to address the unique requirements of banking apps. The paper also explores the challenges, including security, data management, and integration with legacy banking systems, that come with adopting serverless technologies. Finally, the paper discusses performance and scalability considerations, security concerns, and potential future enhancements in serverless frameworks, particularly with the integration of AI and blockchain technologies.

detail.abstract: In today's rapidly evolving cloud landscape, enterprises are increasingly adopting multi-cloud strategies to enhance availability, avoid vendor lock-in, and optimize operational costs. However, this architectural shift introduces significant challenges in synchronizing data across heterogeneous cloud platforms in real time. Traditional batch synchronization techniques fail to meet the low-latency and high-throughput demands of modern applications. This paper presents a robust, scalable, and real-time data synchronization architecture leveraging Kafka Stream Processing to ensure consistency and continuity of data across multiple cloud environments. The proposed solution uses Apache Kafka as the central backbone for reliable message brokering and employs Kafka Streams for real-time stream processing, transformation, and enrichment. By strategically deploying Kafka clusters and Kafka Connect across cloud providers like AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud Platform, this architecture enables bi-directional, fault-tolerant, and schema-compliant data replication. Features such as exactly-once semantics, stateful stream transformations, and windowing operations are utilized to maintain strong consistency even during failures or network partitions. Additionally, schema evolution and data validation are supported using Schema Registry integrated with Avro serialization, ensuring interoperability across distributed systems. A comprehensive monitoring layer with Prometheus, Grafana, and Kafka Cruise Control supports observability, performance tuning, and operational resilience. Through simulated test scenarios and case studies, the system demonstrates low synchronization latency (< 2 seconds), high throughput (> 100K msgs/sec), and seamless failover across cloud regions. This research proves that Kafka Stream Processing is not only suitable but highly effective for multi-cloud data synchronization use cases, offering a powerful solution for modern, data-intensive, and distributed enterprise workloads.

detail.abstract: Ayres critiques William Graham Sumner's theory of cultural mores-arguing that their normative variability, described in Folkways, introduces too much noise to serve as a foundation for explaining economic progress. As Ayres writes, "[cultural] mores can make anything right or wrong," underscoring their epistemic instability (Ayres 1978, 206-207; Mayhew 1981, 2). In response, Ayres advances technology as the source of instrumental value-anchored in prediction, experimental science, the "right tool" principle, and the capacity to filter ceremonial noise from meaningful signal. This paper builds on Ayres' instrumental/ceremonial dichotomy by analyzing behavior commonly seen in the manufacturing environment. In modern industrial systems. Fisher Information enables predictive measurement to extract a high-value instrumental signal, while a parallel layer of ceremonial deliberation reinforces and legitimizes those instrumental choices. Industrial process control technology, widely applied in practice, not only demonstrates how individuals are organized to reduce noise and generate value but also reveals how ceremonial processes-such as regulatory validation and cultural endorsement-remain indispensable for sustaining long-term economic progress.

detail.abstract: This paper develops a theoretical extension to the Black-Scholes option pricing model by incorporating sentiment-adjusted implied volatility within a dual-agent framework. We model markets with both sentiment-driven and rational agents, where sentiment affects risk perception without violating noarbitrage conditions. The proposed framework preserves the mathematical elegance of Black-Scholes while providing theoretical foundations for observed behavioral anomalies in options markets. This work contributes to behavioral finance theory by formalizing how psychological factors can be embedded in derivative pricing models.

title: The Judiciary as a fiscal policy tool? Budget stress and judicial decision-making in Brazil

detail.title: The Judiciary as a fiscal policy tool? Budget stress and judicial decision-making in Brazil
detail.abstract: Fiscal policy outcomes are shaped not only by Legislative and Executive actions but also by judicial decisions. To examine if courts respond to fiscal pressures, we analyze 358 binding cases adjudicated by the Brazilian Supreme Court (STF) between 2008 and 2024 involving taxation, pensions, and public budgeting. Using statistical, machine learning, and natural language methods, we find that: (i) government entities win appeals at nearly twice the rate of private parties (62% overall); (ii) worse budget balances correlate with increased pro-government rulings; (iii) when the government loses high-impact cases, the Court modulates decision effects in over 68% of them to reduce budgetary impact; and (iv) consequentialist reasoning increasingly appears in STF opinions during crises. These patterns persist regardless of the ruling party's political orientation, suggesting a structural dynamic in fiscal judicial decisions. Our findings indicate that government financial stress shapes judicial behavior, potentially making the Judiciary an endogenous component of fiscal adjustment.

detail.abstract: A pandemic monitoring system is a web-based software platform designed to collect, track, analyze, and display real-time data on infectious disease outbreaks. Many public health institutions, especially in regions like Africa, face significant challenges in monitoring pandemic trends due to fragmented reporting systems, lack of predictive analytics, and delayed public communication. This project seeks to design and develop a responsive web application that provides a centralized platform for tracking pandemic cases, predicting future outbreaks, issuing real-time notifications, and disseminating verified news updates to users. The design, development, and implementation of pandemic monitoring systems have become critical in public health infrastructure, particularly in responding to fast-spreading diseases such as COVID-19 and Ebola. Existing systems, such as WHO dashboards and CDC outbreak trackers, provide important functionalities but often lack features like integrated AI prediction, user-specific alerts, and local community-level data display—features which our proposed system addresses. The methodology and tools used for the development and deployment of this system follow the AGILE METHODOLOGY for its iterative and user-centered development process. Tools and technologies include Next.js, Node.js, MySQL, Tailwind CSS, and real-time data APIs. System testing showed the platform successfully tracked and visualized case data, allowed admin management of news and user roles, and delivered real-time alerts and notifications. The system also featured an AI-driven chatbot and prediction model to assist users in decision-making. This system successfully implements and extends the core functionalities of pandemic monitoring platforms while offering greater interactivity, flexibility, and real-time public health engagement.

detail.abstract: We provide a theory of financial fragmentation in monetary unions. Our key insight is that currency unions may experience endogenous breakings of symmetry: that is episodes in which identical countries react differently when exposed to the same shock. During these events, part of the union suffers a capital flight, while the rest acts as a safe haven and receives capital inflows. The central bank then faces a difficult trade-off between containing unemployment in capital-flight countries and inflationary pressures in safe-haven ones. By counteracting private capital flows with public ones, anti-fragmentation monetary programs mitigate the impact of financial fragmentation on employment and inflation, thus helping the central bank to fulfil its price stability mandate.

detail.abstract: The imbalance between water resource supply and demand (WSD) significantly hinders the achievement of Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) in the Yellow River Basin (YRB). We introduce the Water Supply and Demand Capacity (WSDC) index to assess WSDC and spatial aggregation effects across 69 cities within the basin. The research examines how urban development, land use, population, and industry influence WSDC and its spatial heterogeneity. Our findings reveal that from 2013 to 2022, water supply in the YRB exhibited a spatial pattern of higher supply in the south and lower supply in the north. While overall water supply increased, some northwestern regions experienced a decline. Water demand was concentrated in high-value areas in the northwest and east, though it generally decreased over time. (2) Urban WSDC demonstrated significant spatial agglomeration, with higher capacity in the south and greater pressure in the northwest and central regions. Concurrently, the number of cities classified as "safe" decreased annually, while those with "high-sensitivity" status increased. Using the optimized GeoDetector model and Geographically and Temporally Weighted Regression (GTWR), we identified key factors influencing WSDC, including average irrigation water use per acre, per capita water resources, and the nighttime light index. These factors varied across years and locations, underscoring the need for tailored water management strategies. (3) Effective water resource management in the YRB must consider the interplay of urban development, land use, population, and industry. Based on our findings, we provide recommendations to mitigate water supply-demand conflicts through targeted management of these factors.

detail.abstract: When independent auditors make judgments under principle-based accounting standards, they tend to be risk-averse in order to avoid the high risk of litigation. Thus, to prevent the gap between the judgments of audit firms and those of individual auditors from widening, auditors deploy certain coping processes. This approach implies that auditors face larger room for discretion as well as greater responsibility in terms of making a professional judgment. In such a circumstance, this study shows that when standards change auditors prefer to rely on existing accounting rules, each auditor's own rules and standards, and shared practices in order to avoid litigation risks, weaken the pressure of aggressive reporting, or reduce the possibility of opinion shopping, namely changing auditors to those that provide favorable opinions to clients.

detail.abstract: This study examines the presence and dynamics of speculative bubbles in AI-related equities using the Generalized Supremum Augmented Dickey-Fuller (GSADF) test and the Markov-Switching GARCH (MS-GARCH) model. The analysis covers a range of U.S. technology stocks, including both well-established large-cap firms and newer AI-focused companies. The GSADF test is employed to detect episodes of explosive price behavior, while the MS-GARCH model captures volatility regime shifts that may accompany speculative phases. The results indicate that among the stocks analyzed, only NVIDIA and Tesla exhibited statistically significant bubble-like dynamics, notably around 2019 and again in early 2024, reflecting episodes of heightened market optimism unrelated to the initial surge in generative AI enthusiasm. Other firms commonly associated with the AI theme such as Meta, Snowflake, Palantir, and MongoDB did not show clear signs of speculative price behavior over the observed period. These findings suggest that the recent AI boom has not led to widespread asset price bubbles across the sector but has instead been concentrated in a small number of key stocks. The study emphasizes the importance of distinguishing between structural valuation growth and speculative acceleration when evaluating emerging technology markets. Limitations related to sample size and test sensitivity are also discussed to inform future research.

detail.abstract: Endogamous marriages in India reflect a socially segregated society based on religion and caste, perpetuating the existing social stratification and inequalities. Caste endogamy contributes to the unequal transfer of social capital and social endowments, thereby reproducing inequalities within and across generations. In this background, the study examined the question of whether Inter-caste marriages contribute to reducing economic inequality in children's nutrition. We triangulated analyses based on pooled microdata and macro-panel data compiled from the National Family Health Survey and other Government surveys (2005-2021). The Wagstaff's corrected concentration index, panel data random effects regression models, and pooled cross-sectional probit regression model have been used. Findings suggest the continued prevalence of caste-based assortative sorting in the Indian marriage market and wealth-based inequalities in child nutritional status, thereby indicating both strong caste endogamy and health inequalities. However, an increase in Inter-caste marriage is associated with declining inequalities in the child nutrition indicators: stunting, wasting, and underweight. The pathway is established through the reduced economic heterogeneity in populations owing to inter-caste marital arrangements and a greater possibility of exchange of resources. Thus, we advance that Inter-caste marriages lessen caste inequalities in child nutrition in India by narrowing group differences in socioeconomic status.

title: Process-Oriented Standards In Shareholder Protection Under Chinese Law: An Empirical Analysis

detail.title: Process-Oriented Standards In Shareholder Protection Under Chinese Law: An Empirical Analysis
detail.abstract:
The law and finance literature posits that courts in common law jurisdictions can apply flexible fiduciary duty standards and are therefore more effective than courts in civil law jurisdictions at protecting minority shareholders. This Article revisits this claim by conducting several empirical studies on cases involving related-party transactions, share buybacks, and the modification of control rights in China. To better analyze the regulatory approaches, this Article identifies four distinct regulatory strategies: substance-oriented rules, process-oriented rules, substance-oriented standards, and process-oriented standards. The findings show that Chinese courts currently utilize the first three approaches. They apply both rules and standards, but the standards are predominantly substance-oriented. In contrast, process-oriented standards, which are more typical in common law jurisdictions, are largely absent in the Chinese context.

This Article further argues that process-oriented standards offer important advantages over substance-oriented rules and standards in certain circumstances, as they alleviate the concerns about information disadvantages and institutional incompetence. They are also more flexible than process-oriented rules in protecting minority shareholders. This Article then examines both institutional and conceptual limitations to developing process-oriented standards in China. It argues that institutional constraints do not constitute insurmountable barriers. Chinese courts are already working with open-ended standards in several types of corporate disputes. In addition, courts possess greater authority than some listed corporations and most non-listed corporations. The absence of process-oriented standards is more likely attributable to the conceptual limitations.

title: Mineral Fixation by Design: How the West Engineered Africa’s Resource Dependency and Economic Underdevelopment

detail.abstract:
This policy paper demonstrates that Africa’s fixation on mineral resources as the engine of economic development is not a naturally occurring strategy but a deliberately engineered framework. Promoted by and for Western interests, this model has led to misguided policies, chronic stagnation, and deepening dependency. This externally imposed narrative serves four strategic purposes: (1) distract African policymakers from adopting sound, liberating economic models, (2) maintain Africa’s role as a cheap commodity supplier, (3) sustain neocolonial control and repression through autocratic governance, and (4) perpetuate economic underdevelopment and Western domination.

The mineral-resource model not only perpetuates economic instability, stagnation, and dependency but also sustains authoritarian regimes and statist systems that repress Africa’s greatest asset: its people, particularly the youth and their productive, entrepreneurial capacity. These coercive and confiscatory systems entrench structural injustices while suppressing human flourishing.

Africonomics offers a principled and liberating alternative grounded in structural justice, human dignity, and productive agency. Through free enterprise, sound money (the Nilar), and continent-wide economic integration, African nations can move beyond mineral dependency and statist economics to build integrated, stable, and thriving economies, thereby restoring African sovereignty and dignity.

detail.abstract: This study introduces the Post-Shock Elastic Recovery Index (PERI), a novel composite metric designed to quantify the speed and strength of economic recovery following exogenous shocks. By integrating output rebound, fiscal space, institutional trust, and trade openness in a multiplicative framework, PERI offers a comprehensive measure of economic resilience. Using a panel dataset of 30 OECD countries from 2008 to 2020, we validate PERI's predictive power through robust econometric analyses, including fixed-effects regressions and sensitivity tests. Results demonstrate that a one-unit increase in PERI is associated with a 0.87% increase in subsequent GDP growth (p < 0.01), highlighting its utility for policymakers. PERI's unique structure distinguishes it from existing indices, making it a timely tool for navigating recurring global disruptions, such as financial crises and pandemics.

detail.abstract: This study develops a conceptual simulation model for a tokenized recycling incentive system that integrates blockchain infrastructure, market-driven pricing, behavioral economics, and carbon credit mechanisms. The model aims to address the limitations of traditional recycling systems, which often rely on static government subsidies and fail to generate sustained public participation. By introducing dynamic token values linked to realworld supply and demand conditions, as well as incorporating non-monetary behavioral drivers (e.g., social norms, reputational incentives), the framework creates a dual-incentive structure that can adapt over time. The model uses Monte Carlo simulations to estimate outcomes under a range of scenarios involving operational costs, carbon pricing, token volatility, and behavioral adoption rates. Due to the absence of real-world implementations of such integrated blockchain-based recycling systems, the paper remains theoretical and simulationbased. It is intended as a prototype framework for future policy experimentation and pilot projects. The model provides insights for policymakers, urban planners, and technology developers aiming to explore decentralized and market-responsive solutions to sustainable waste management. Future work should focus on validating the model through field trials or behavioral experiments.

detail.abstract: Recent research suggests that earnings forecasts generated by machine learning (ML) models are more accurate than those produced by traditional regression models and financial analysts. We extend the literature by comparing the accuracy of earnings forecasts generated by ML models with those provided by corporate managers (i.e., management earnings forecasts). This study focuses on Japan, where management earnings forecasts are effectively mandated. We employ k-nearest neighbors, random forest, and deep neural networks as representative ML models. Using a sample of Japanese listed firms from 2002 to 2023, we find that management earnings forecasts are more accurate than ML earnings forecasts. Among the three ML models, deep neural networks achieve the highest forecasting accuracy, followed by k-nearest neighbors and then random forest. These findings underscore the informational advantage of corporate managers in forecasting firm performance, despite recent advances in ML. They also suggest that the choice of algorithm matters: more complex models such as deep neural networks may outperform simpler alternatives when predicting future earnings.

detail.abstract: Agent-based models (ABMs) are powerful computational tools for simulating complex socioeconomic systems, where numerous interacting agents engage in transactions based on personal expectations, leading to dynamic system states. While ABMs may be well-suited to capture these interactions, their simulations can be computationally expensive. A promising solution is the use of machine learning-based meta-models, or surrogates, which approximate the ABM outputs without the need to run the whole simulation. While previous research has primarily used machine learning for sensitivity analysis and calibration, this paper presents a novel technique by employing machine learning surrogates to forecast the outcome of policy interventions in the Keynes meeting Schumpeter ABM, by training the machine learning models on the results of various simulations. Five machine learning techniques-XGBoost, feed-forward artificial neural network, support vector machine, random forest, K-nearest neighbors-are evaluated for their ability to predict different macroeconomic variables, and model performance is assessed using the mean squared error to identify the surrogate that most accurately forecasts ABM outputs. Results indicate XGBoost methods as the best approximation of the ABM output. The current research thus contributes to the field by providing a computationally efficient approach for policy evaluation in ABMs and may provide additional insights for the design of more informed economic interventions via the use of simulation methods.

detail.abstract: The intricate relationship between global conflicts and economic growth has remained a pressing concern in both academic and policy-making circles. In a world increasingly affected by geopolitical tensions, territorial disputes, terrorism, trade wars, and ideological clashes, it is crucial to examine how such conflicts shape the economic trajectories of nations and regions. This study aims to provide a comprehensive analysis of the short-term disruptions and long-term structural impacts of global conflicts on economic growth, using a combination of theoretical exploration, empirical data, and real-world case studies. While the economic consequences of war and conflict have been addressed in prior literature, there remains a significant gap in understanding the broader, interconnected effects of modern, multi-dimensional conflicts on global and national economic systems.

detail.abstract: This paper compares China and the United States as bilateral donors and global competitors to examine the existence of a 'vanguard effect' in their aid and FDI flows to developing world, i.e. aid from a particular donor promotes FDI from the same country. It introduces an aid identification model treating aid allocation as a simultaneous optimization problem, considering the perceived costs and benefits for both donors and recipients. Empirical results reveal no consistent, statistically significant evidence in support of a vanguard effect. While Chinese aid shows some positive, though inconsistent, association with Chinese FDI, this pattern is less evident for the U.S. Notably, higher U.S. aid correlates with increased Chinese FDI, but higher Chinese aid does not lead to more U.S. FDI. Improving trade balances with the U.S. attracts FDI from both countries, whereas similar improvements with China may crowd out Chinese FDI. Economic variables largely explain U.S. FDI, whereas Chinese FDI, in the presence of Chinese aid, is more influenced by political factors. Chinese aid boosts FDI via increased state involvement but deters it when state capacity and productivity rise. Regionally, U.S. aid positively affects FDI in Sub-Saharan Africa, while Chinese aid and FDI are significantly correlated in East Asia and the Pacific. The findings suggest recipient countries may face a trade-off between the Eagle and the Dragon: attracting U.S. FDI may require openness, stronger institutions, and export growth, while courting Chinese FDI in the presence of Chinese aid could come at the expense of these very factors.

detail.title: The Role of Shadow Banking in Economic Stability: Examining its Mechanisms, Benefits, and Risks
detail.abstract: Shadow banking is vital to the global financial system as it serves as the unregulated alternative to traditional banking with its ability to offer a great deal of liquidity and access to credit. The different classes of shadow banking entities including hedge funds and securitization operations impact economic stability as it allows capital to flow freely irrespective of the various banking regulations. Nevertheless, on the contrary, shadow banking also has the associated dangers as evidenced by the 2008 financial meltdown which demonstrated how its unregulated nature leads to systemic instability. In this regard, several key points have been highlighted in this paper to understand the associated risks and thus the need for policies to ensure potential risks are properly handled. Hence, in this regard, there is a need for regulatory authorities to apply and implement policies that can adequately respond to the risks posed by shadow banking such as the implications of some aspects of Basel Ill to ensure the financial system is properly protected against potential dangers whilst allowing the growth of shadow banking and its associated benefits.

title: Analyzing the Survival and Migration of Light-Duty Vehicles Across the United States1
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Government of the United States of America - Oak Ridge National Laboratory and Government of the United States of America - Oak Ridge National Laboratory

detail.title: Analyzing the Survival and Migration of Light-Duty Vehicles Across the United States1

keywords.keywords: Light-duty vehiclesUsed vehiclesVehicle survivalVehicle scrappageVehicle migrationState vehicle markets

detail.abstract: The transition to electric vehicles (EVs) will be a complex and multidecadal process of systemic change. For the U.S., because of the large differences in EV adoption across states, important components of the transition include migration of used vehicles across states and their rates of survival. To assess how vehicles transition across states over time, we estimate a model of state-level vehicle net survival, which incorporates the combined effects of vehicle migration and survival. Using state-level data on vehicle registrations during 2015-2022, we estimate how vehicle net survival varies with vehicle age, class, and state employment, income, and population. Although our data does not disentangle scrappage from migration, our analysis indicates substantial and persistent flows of 2- to 10-year-old vehicles among states that respond to differences in economic and population growth and other state attributes with potentially important implications for the diffusion of advanced automotive technologies. We show that the COVID pandemic had drastic but short-lived effects on the net survival rates of older vehicles, especially light trucks. We estimate statistical models of state net survival rates for passenger cars, sport utility vehicles (SUV) and vans, and pickup trucks that can be used in constructing vehicle adoption scenarios.

title: The Effects of Flipped Classrooms in Higher Education: A Causal Machine Learning Analysis
affiliations: Heinrich Heine University Dusseldorf, Heinrich Heine University Dusseldorf - Department of Economics, Heinrich Heine University Dusseldorf and University of Bayreuth

detail.title: The Effects of Flipped Classrooms in Higher Education: A Causal Machine Learning Analysis
detail.abstract: This study uses double/debiased machine learning to evaluate the impact of transitioning from lecture-based blended teaching to a flipped classroom concept in a cohort comparison of a large compulsory introductory statistics course at a German tuition-free university. Our findings indicate positive changes in students' self-conception and a reduction in procrastination behaviors. However, we also observe a decline in the enjoyment of classroom sessions. Contrary to theoretical expectations, we do not find significant positive effects on exam scores, passing rates, or knowledge retention. Unlike most studies, however, we can leverage detailed usage data from the flipped cohort, including the timeliness and completeness of pre-class video watching, as well as quiz participation patterns, to check how well students implemented each part of the curriculum. Our findings suggest that, on average, students in the flipped cohort implemented the instructional approach insufficiently, explaining the mechanism of our null results in exam performance and knowledge retention. This highlights the need for additional strategies to ensure that students actually benefit from a flipped curriculum.

title: Waterway as Greenway: The Environmental Impacts and Valuation of Massive Water Diversion Project1
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Waterway as Greenway: The Environmental Impacts and Valuation of Massive Water Diversion Project1
detail.abstract: This paper examines the environmental impacts and valuation of a major water diversion project in China, the Central Route of the South-to-North Water Transfer Project. Utilizing remote-sensing data for vegetation indices and a comprehensive dataset of urban land transactions, I employed a difference-in-difference approach to analyze the project’s effects on nearby ecological conditions and urban land prices. My analysis reveals a significant improvement in vegetation within a 5-km radius of the canal postoperation, accompanied by a substantial increase in urban land prices. Heterogeneity analysis across different land use types indicates that environmental improvement is factored into the land prices. This suggests a huge environmental value and complements the concurrent welfare analysis of water infrastructure.

title: Does Bank Sponsorship Matter During Banking Crisis: Evidence from the US Money Market Funds
affiliations: Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)

detail.title: Does Bank Sponsorship Matter During Banking Crisis: Evidence from the US Money Market Funds
detail.abstract: This study examines the effect of the 2023 United States banking crisis due to the Fed interest rate hikes on the Money Market Funds (MMFs) industry. Using the Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) failure as an exogenous shock to the banking industry, we show that prime MMFs experience significant outflows during that period. We do not find any evidence that funds' weekly level liquidity (WLA) triggers any outflows during the crisis period. Further analysis shows that even if WLA goes below the threshold level, it does not cause any impact on the fund flows. In a novel result, we show that prime MMFs sponsored by banks experience significantly higher fund outflow as compared to their peers. Moreover, we also show that retail prime funds with an ex-ante exposure to Financial Commercial Papers (FinCPs) experience significant outflows during the period.

title: Le problème du pouvoir privé à l'ère du numérique : vers une (re-)constitutionnalisation du droit de la concurrence ? (The Problem of Private Power in the Digital Era: Towards a (Re-)Constitutionalization of Competition Law?)

detail.abstract:
French Abstract: La présente contribution, à paraître dans l'ouvrage collectif Constitutionnalisme numérique, jette un regard critique sur les appels à attribuer au droit de la concurrence un rôle constitutionnel de protection de l’ordre constitutionnel libéral-démocratique.
