La présente contribution n'en entrevoit pas moins un potentiel constitutionnel pour le droit de la concurrence dans un domaine où la doctrine n'a eu de cesse de l'ignorer ou d'en minimiser l'apport : le processus de constitutionnalisation des espaces numériques gouvernés par les plateformes. La notion d’abus d’exploitation en particulier a démontré sa capacité à intervenir dans les interstices des réglementations ciblées pour promouvoir le respect de valeurs de type constitutionnel au bénéfice des utilisateurs des plateformes numériques dominantes.

English Abstract: This contribution, forthcoming in Digital Constitutionalism, takes a critical look at the calls to give competition law a constitutional role in protecting the liberal-democratic constitutional order. While ideas abound, the have yet to translate into an empirically grounded and proportionate operational approach that comports with the economic objectives of competition law.


Nevertheless, this contribution sees constitutional potential for competition law in an area where the literature has consistently ignored or minimized its role: the process of constitutionalizing digital spaces governed by platforms. The concept of an exploitative abuse in particular has demonstrated its ability to fill the gaps between targeted regulations to promote constitutional values to the benefit of users of dominant digital platforms

title: Mental Mapping of the Border between Western and Eastern Europe: Transforming Conceptions
affiliations: MGIMO (Moscow State University of International Relations), MGIMO (Moscow State University of International Relations) and MGIMO (Moscow State University of International Relations)

detail.title: Mental Mapping of the Border between Western and Eastern Europe: Transforming Conceptions
detail.abstract: The article presents the results of using mental mapping in studying the concept of the border between Western and Eastern Europe. Since the collapse of the USSR the border under study has been transforming due to the aspirations of certain post-Soviet countries as well as the expanding scope of the Euro-Atlantic integration. The study is based on the survey of the MGIMO first-year students who drew the border between Eastern and Western Europe on a map and answered questions on travel frequency and Russia’s belonging to Europe. Three waves of the survey have been conducted sofar: in 2022 (before February 22), 2023 and 2024. This group of the respondents is of special interest, because they may form the core of Russia’s diplomacy in future. According to the survey, the “main” border of Western and Eastern Europe lies along the following route: the border between Russia and Finland — the Finnish Gulf — the Baltic Sea — the border between Poland and Germany — the border between the Check Republic and Germany — the border between the Check Republic and Austria — the border between Austria and Slovakia — the border between Austria and Hungary. This pattern overall remained the same over the whole period, however, in 2023 and 2024 the border became clearer, for instance, Croatia was more rarely identified as an Eastern European state, and the Baltics were more rarely attached to Western Europe. More frequent travelers were inclined to provide a more detailed and less stereotype pattern of the border. The study revealed unexpected gender differences in answers: women were more likely to push the border of the Eastern Europe closer to Russia.

title: The Impact of Single Sales Factor Apportionment on State Tax Revenues: Short-and Long-Run Effects
affiliations: Stanford University - Hoover Institution

detail.title: The Impact of Single Sales Factor Apportionment on State Tax Revenues: Short-and Long-Run Effects
detail.abstract: Since 1978, forty U.S. states changed the formulas determining their corporate income tax bases. The most common change has been from a definition of taxable corporate income consisting of payroll, property, and sales within the state, to one consisting solely of sales ("Single Sales Factor Apportionment"). This paper estimates the effects of these changes on a state's taxable corporate income. Descriptive evidence suggests that taxable corporate income increases initially following the policy adoption; however, using a combination of two-way fixed effects, difference-in-differences, and synthetic approaches, I estimate that corporate income generally remains unchanged or declines over time, with most effects negative but statistically insignificant.

title: The Market for Block Space: A Microstructure Lens on Decentralized Payment Networks
affiliations: Macquarie University, Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich (LMU), Queen's University - Smith School of Business and The University of Sydney - Discipline of Finance

detail.title: The Market for Block Space: A Microstructure Lens on Decentralized Payment Networks
detail.abstract: We use Ethereum's 2021 London upgrade (EIP‑1559) to examine the impact of fee pricing and allocation mechanisms on the market quality of decentralized payment networks. Introducing a semi-uniform auction pricing that burns base fees stabilizes some aspects of fee volatility, but increases average fee and dispersion and leads to higher inflation for users. Miners earn higher public subsidies per average transaction and, paradoxically, allow less on-chain activity and monetary value transferred through dynamically adjusted block sizes. The transition to Proof of Stake provides a setting for a placebo test that reinforces the main findings. These results highlight the importance of calibrating both fee pricing and space allocation in blockchain protocols. Even modest changes in these parameters can produce large, systematic welfare effects on on‑chain liquidity, user costs, and network usability.

title: The Recent Compression of US Wage Inequality: Tightness, Turbulence, and Power-Biased Policy
affiliations: The University of Manchester - Global Development Institute and University of Massachusetts at Amherst - College of Social and Behavioral Sciences - Department of Economics

detail.title: The Recent Compression of US Wage Inequality: Tightness, Turbulence, and Power-Biased Policy
detail.abstract: Expansionary fiscal policy and tight post-pandemic labour markets have been seen as correctives to decades of macro-policy that contributed to rising inequality in the US. Reviewing the evidence for and against this perspective, our findings accord with studies that show labour market conditions as an important determinant of nominal wage dynamics. However, the dramatic compression of wage inequality during the recent pandemic and its aftermath was driven primarily by special circumstances, including power-biased policy intervention. Moreover, we caution against interpretations that extend the cyclical relationship between labour market tightness and wage inequality to the long run.

title: The Effect of Quantitative and Qualitative Scope 3 Emissions Disclosures on Investor Judgments
affiliations: University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign - Department of Accountancy and University of Virginia - McIntire School of Commerce

detail.title: The Effect of Quantitative and Qualitative Scope 3 Emissions Disclosures on Investor Judgments
detail.abstract: The SEC Climate Rule requires firms to disclose Scope 1 (direct) and Scope 2 (energy consumption) emissions, but not Scope 3 (value chain) emissions. This omission raises concerns that investors lack sufficient information to assess firms’ overall climate impact. As a result, investors might reward firms that reduce their Scope 1 emissions by outsourcing to suppliers and penalize firms that insource production, thereby increasing their Scope 1 emissions. Using experimentation, we find that investors are misled by firms outsourcing emissions to the unreported Scope 3 category. Although disclosing Scope 3 emissions metrics attenuates favorable views toward “carbon outsourcers,” the ambiguity surrounding the reasons for emissions changes hinders investors from fully differentiating between carbon outsourcers and carbon insourcers. However, including qualitative explanations helps reduce this ambiguity. Our findings highlight the importance of comprehensive emissions disclosures in improving transparency and helping investors to make informed decisions, offering valuable implications for regulators and policymakers.

title: Health Risk and Economic Value: Quantifying the Insurance, Financial, and Fiscal Implications of Reducing Disease Burden

detail.abstract: We quantify the shadow cost of incomplete health insurance as the additional premium individuals are willing to pay to avoid health shocks (WTP). Using 18.5 million diagnoses from 6.9 million people, we estimate the causal effects of 334 health shocks on financial and labor outcomes. These estimates feed into a calibrated life-cycle model, yielding WTP values ranging from 10-33% of annual income for cancers and 6-35% for cardiovascular diseases (CVD). Under public insurance with equal premiums, the maximum investment in cancer prevention is 2% of GDP (1.2% for CVD); progressive premiums raise this figure to 10.6%, while maintaining overall welfare.

title: Remote Work and Child Penalties
affiliations: Princeton University

detail.title: Remote Work and Child Penalties
detail.abstract: This paper studies how remote work affects child penalties in employment, using pseudo-event studies around childbirth in four Latin American countries. Using complementary empirical strategies at the individual, household, and regional level, I find that remote work reduces the child penalty by about 4 percentage points, relative to a baseline penalty of nearly 17 points. These effects operate through three main channels: (i) women in occupations that can be done from home are more likely to remain in their pre-child job; (ii) recent mothers are more likely to transition into remote work; (iii) women whose partners can work from home are more likely to remain employed. The post-pandemic increase in remote work brought higher-quality (formal, salaried and higher-paying) jobs, making these effects stronger. These findings suggest that policies supporting access to remote work may help reduce gender gaps in labor outcomes.

title: How Exposed Are Banks to Physical Climate Risk?
affiliations: UNSW Australia Business School, School of Banking and Finance, ESCP Business School and The University of Sydney - Discipline of Finance

detail.title: How Exposed Are Banks to Physical Climate Risk?
detail.abstract: We develop a framework to quantify banks' exposure to physical climate risk using temperature anomaly factors derived from high-frequency local and global climate data. These factors capture systematic climate variability, predict disaster frequency and severity, and explain bank-level return dynamics. Estimated climate betas reveal substantial heterogeneity in banks' exposures, translating into systemic physical climate risk exceeding 500 billion dollars by the late 2010s. Our framework offers a practical tool for integrating physical climate risk into financial regulation and stress testing.

title: Deterrence and Industrial Wars of Attrition
affiliations: Bocconi University - Department of Economics

detail.title: Deterrence and Industrial Wars of Attrition
detail.abstract: Industrial wars of attrition are drawn-out conflicts where victory is decided in large part by which combatant is able to outproduce its opponent in terms of military materiel. This paper argues that under the risk of such a war, industrial capacity in the defence sector and its supply chains generates a national security externality, as it can deter a potential aggressor from invading. Using a simple macroeconomic model, I show that in a decentralized equilibrium, atomistic investors underinvest in defence industrial capacity, as they do not internalize this effect. Governments can significantly improve upon this outcome by subsidizing immobile factors in these industries, and can achieve the first-best outcome if they are able to commit to wartime weapon purchases.

title: What Is My Home Worth?
affiliations: Federal Reserve Banks - Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia and Federal Reserve Banks - Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia

detail.title: What Is My Home Worth?
detail.abstract: Economic models often assume that agents always know the market value of their assets. We use residential property tax assessment as a laboratory to test this assumption for housing. We first show that assessed market value (AMV) is a noisy proxy for transaction-based market values (TMV). Innovations in AMV are less volatile, are weakly correlated with, and lag innovations in TMV. An AMV-based, national-level house price index has shallower troughs and shorter peaks than its TMV-based counterpart. We merge in credit bureau data to test whether homeowners use AMVs, as signals of housing wealth, to make consumption decisions. Using local mass reassessments as an instrument and conditional of TMV changes, we find that AMV increases causally raise the likelihood that households take out a new home equity line of credit (HELOC). A partial equilibrium calibration exercise suggests that annual HELOC origination would have been 0.5% higher after the Global Financial Crisis if AMV mirrored TMV. Overall, our results suggest that homeowners do not know the value of their homes.

title: Federalism in the Adjudicative State
affiliations: New York University School of Law

detail.title: Federalism in the Adjudicative State
detail.abstract:
By many accounts, administrative adjudication is in crisis. Congressional design choices and the Supreme Court’s embrace of unitary executive theory have increasingly subordinated everyday adjudication to top-down presidential control. The present regime radically departs from the model of neutral decisionmaking by insulated adjudicators envisioned in the Administrative Procedure Act.

Or so the prevailing narrative goes. Although not inaccurate, this narrative is incomplete. Absent from the picture—and from administrative law scholarship generally—is the significant role that states play in adjudication. Using illustrative examples from across the administrative state, this Article reveals that much of federal agency adjudication is cooperative:  states and federal agencies performing different adjudicative roles often jointly decide individual entitlements. What’s more, these “cooperative adjudications” challenge foundational premises about the adjudicative state. They not only expand our understandings of the forms that agency adjudication can take, but also complicate the prevailing account of how the adjudicative state is structured. In place of top-down presidential control, legal authority in these programs is plural and fragmented—the adjudication process is divided between multiple principals; there is separation between different adjudicative functions; and bottom-up accountability serves as a check on top-down political influence.

Finally, this more plural view requires us to revise our normative assumptions about the proper role of politics in agency adjudications. Rather than a contaminant to be cleansed, I argue that politics in adjudications should be a feature to be managed. Given the inevitability of political control over the adjudicative state, political pluralism may be a next-best solution to safeguard individual outcomes from being dictated by a single political hierarchy. And contrary to conventional wisdom, local judgment and public participation can be valuable inputs into the resolution of individual claims. This Article offers considerations for institutional designers to manage these political forces.

title: Transaction Costs and the Stochastic Discount Factor
affiliations: Queen Mary University of London, Queen Mary University of London - School of Economics and Finance and Queen Mary University of London - School of Economics and Finance

detail.title: Transaction Costs and the Stochastic Discount Factor
detail.abstract: We show that transaction costs fundamentally reshape the stochastic discount factor (SDF) by determining which characteristics matter in equilibrium. Using deep neural networks, we incorporate transaction costs directly into robust SDF estimation rather than treating them as post-optimization adjustments or arbitrary investment constraints. Transaction cost-aware SDFs yield substantially higher net Sharpe ratios and superior cross-sectional pricing through endogenous portfolio reallocation: increased diversification, reduced turnover, and lower exposure to costly high-turnover characteristics. These effects persist across sample configurations, market regimes, neural network specifications, and alternative definitions of transaction costs, demonstrating that trading frictions are structural determinants of equilibrium asset prices.

title: Between the Second and the Third Worlds: The Legal Postcoloniality of Central Asia
affiliations: University of Glasgow - School of Law

detail.title: Between the Second and the Third Worlds: The Legal Postcoloniality of Central Asia
detail.abstract: How can we understand the basic character of Central Asia's postcoloniality for international law purposes? The fall of the USSR thirty years ago brought an end to Russia’s direct political rule over Central Asia. But the arrival of formal independence was not matched by a parallel decoupling of the deeper structure of legal and institutional regimes. Something broadly similar had happened before to the former British and French colonies. What distinguishes the Central Asian case, however, is the vector of the formal shift – Central Asian states gained independence from the preeminent power of the ‘Second World’, not the ‘First World’– and the rather distinct character of the post-independence transition processes. In many cases, these processes, choreographed and coordinated through a network of international institutions not existent at  the time of the previous wave of decolonisation, were shaped not just by a local aspiration towards independence but also an intense external pressure to adopt a particular combination of Western-style legal and political reform packages. A large part of what accounts for the way this pressure came to be practised was the rise of a certain kind of international law imaginary: a combination of sanctioned ignorance, a firm belief in 'legal science', and a version of 'civilising mission'. The one crucial element that brought this complex together at the ideological level  was the consistent exoticization of Central Asia via the implicit denial of its postcolonial status. The structural shift that allowed it to turn into a practically active legal regime was the replacement of the traditional modes of international coercion with modern-day techniques of 'adverse publicity'. As one set of colonial forms and dynamics gave way to another, the question of Central Asia's postcoloniality, already made ideologically opaque by the ‘second-worldist’ origins of the Soviet empire, quickly receded further into the background. What made this process of obfuscation even more effective at the theoretical level, in international law, was the persisting failure on the part of the international law academia to maintain any degree of  interest in the region. As the task of determining how international law and its institutions should approach and understand Central Asia essentially fell to non-lawyers, the resulting narrative about Central Asia and its place in the international arena took on increasingly neocolonialist overtones of the kind one would rarely see admitted in relation to other non-Western regions. The fact that the predominant mode of thinking postcoloniality in international legal thought at this time took the form of 'Third World Approaches to International Law' certainly did not help, as it helped relegate Central Asia even further beyond the limits of critical attention among the discipline's critically attuned scholarly segment. This chapter is an attempt to push back against this trend. In critiquing the traditional international law conception of Central Asia that has emerged over the last thirty years and in rethinking the shape of Central Asia's (legal) postcoloniality, it offers reflections not only about the basic relationship between post-Sovietness and postcoloniality but also the broader challenge of conceptualising decolonisation, neocolonialism, and postcoloniality in international legal thought.

title: A Dynamic Framework for Liquidity-Driven Investment Friction
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: A Dynamic Framework for Liquidity-Driven Investment Friction
detail.abstract: This paper dismantles the Gaussian dominating investment cost models by demonstrating that transaction costs-particularly dynamic bid-ask spreads-follow non-Gaussian, regimedependent distributions with profound implications for performance measurement, portfolio construction, and regulatory disclosure. I present three breakthroughs: • A Three-Layer Cost Model integrating (1) Gaussian fixed fees, (2) Lévy-distributed spreads, and (3) extreme-event liquidity shocks, validated against 2008/2020 crises. • The Liquidity-Adjusted Cost Metric (LACM), showing traditional models underestimate tail costs by 4-9x, especially for active strategies (2.8% annual drag) and private assets (3.8% hidden spread costs). • Regulatory Solutions, including stress-tested spread disclosures and liquidity "bucket" labels to protect investors from $4.7B+ in annual hidden costs. Empirically, i prove 82% of trading days exhibit non-Gaussian cost dynamics, while behavioral experiments reveal 83% of investors underestimate spread impacts by 2-5x. The framework provides actionable tools for asset managers, quant funds, and, possibly, to policymakers-finally bridging microstructure theory with real-world portfolio management.

publicationDetails.detailsText: European Banking Institute Working Paper Series No.193

detail.abstract:
The present study seeks to identify the impact of recent and current geopolitical risks and tensions on the existing international financial architecture. Its scope is confined to institutional and legal aspects and does not extend to the dynamics of international relations. The study is structured in three Sections as follows:

Section 1 sets the scene by providing a brief but coherent overview of the international financial architecture, as this has developed since the 1970ies as part of the rules-based international order and the overall international economic governance. 

The following Section 2 discusses the current situation in relation to this architecture through the lens of recent and current geopolitical risks and tensions. It firstly gives a definition of the term “geopolitical risks” (under 2.1) and then focuses on the risks to financial stability in the EU from geopolitical tensions on the occasion of the closure of Sberbank in Europe in February 2022 amidst the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and then on the basis of the recent (since then) and current concerns of public authorities in relation to EU financial stability (under 2.2). Finally (and most importantly), it overviews the sustainability of the international financial architecture, by briefly discussing countries’ compliance with international financial standards in the example of the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (BCBS), and exploring the potential threats to the maintenance of the existing international financial architecture (under 2.3).

Section 3 concludes by a brief assessment.

title: Short-Term Forecasting of Reservoir Water Levels for Recreation Management: A Case Study from Taiwan
affiliations: University of Graz

detail.title: Short-Term Forecasting of Reservoir Water Levels for Recreation Management: A Case Study from Taiwan
detail.abstract: Reservoirs are vital for water supply, flood control, and recreation. In tourism-dependent areas, sudden fluctuations in reservoir water levels can jeopardize visitor safety and disrupt site operations. This study presents a short-term forecasting framework for hourly reservoir water levels using high-frequency, real-time data from Taiwan's Water Resources Agency. We evaluate and compare two forecasting models-SARIMAX and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) neural networks-based on predictive accuracy and operational utility. Using a two-week dataset from June and July 2025, we find that the LSTM model outperforms SARIMAX, reducing RMSE by 15% and improving the precision of safe/unsafe shoreline alerts. These results have clear implications for smart tourism management, enabling more proactive decisions about dock closures, visitor warnings, and emergency planning. Our findings support the integration of machine learning into reservoir-adjacent recreational planning and highlight the benefits of open data policies. While the study is limited by its short temporal scope, it offers a replicable foundation for scalable, real-time forecasting in tourism infrastructure.

title: Inequality and Mobility Under Social Competition
affiliations: University of Genoa and Ca Foscari University of Venice - Dipartimento di Economia

detail.title: Inequality and Mobility Under Social Competition

publicationDetails.detailsText: Ca' Foscari University of Venice, Department of Economics Research Paper Series No. 9
publicationDetails.journalName: Department of Economics, Ca' Foscari University of Venice Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: We provide a micro-founded dynamic framework to analyse the effects of inequality on social competition, mobility, and welfare. We consider an infinitely repeated Tullock contest in which players with concave utility allocate resources between consumption and costly effort, and the prizes from the current competition determine the players' endowments in the subsequent period. We characterize the unique pure-strategy Markov Perfect Equilibrium, proving that the highly endowed player exerts more effort and has a higher probability of winning. Social competition is maximized at an intermediate level of inequality, whereas utilitarian social welfare is maximized under full equality. Assuming non-increasing absolute risk aversion preferences, we find that greater inequality monotonically reduces social mobility (a pattern consistent with the Great Gatsby curve) and lowers the welfare of the lowly endowed player. By contrast, the welfare of the highly endowed player is non-monotonic when the discount factor is sufficiently high. Thus, being richer in a more unequal society does not necessarily imply higher individual welfare. For example, under logarithmic utility and = 2=3, an individual must control over 88% of total resources to strictly prefer inequality over full equality.

title: Climate Change and Financial Vulnerability of Rural Households in China: Evidence from Chfs
affiliations: Xihua University, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Southwestern University of Finance and Economics (SWUFE)

detail.title: Climate Change and Financial Vulnerability of Rural Households in China: Evidence from Chfs
detail.abstract: Against the backdrop of increasing global warming, studying climate change's economic and social impacts has become a hot topic in academia and policy circles in recent years. Based on five rounds of survey data from the China Household Finance Survey (CHFS) from 2011-2019, which are matched with meteorological data at the county levels, this paper assesses the microeconomic consequences of climate change by identifying the causal effect of temperature change on the financial vulnerability of rural households in China. It is found that climate warming significantly exacerbates the financial vulnerability of rural households, with the likelihood of a rural household being financially vulnerable increasing by 3.16% for every 1°C increase in average temperature. Mechanism tests indicate that climate warming mainly exacerbates financial vulnerability by lowering household income and elevating health risks and credit constraints. Heterogeneity analyses show that the impacts of climate warming are significantly pro-poor at the household and regional levels. Based on the temperature change paths in the middle (2040-2069) and long-term (2070-2099) of the 21st century, this paper predicts the potential impacts of future global warming on the financial vulnerability of China's farm households. The results show that future global warming may increase the proportion of farm households in financial distress in China by 3.99%-8.38% in the medium term and by 5.38%-11.48% in the long term. This paper provides a new perspective on the economic consequences of climate change from the perspective of micro households, as well as micro evidence of the importance of consolidating and expanding the achievements of poverty eradication, comprehensively promoting the strategy of rural revitalization, and actively andsteadily advancing the dual-carbon strategy.

title: Improving Adherence to an Online Intervention for Low Mood by a Virtual Coach or Personalized Motivational Feedback Messages: A Three-Arm Pilot Randomized Controlled Trial

detail.title: Improving Adherence to an Online Intervention for Low Mood by a Virtual Coach or Personalized Motivational Feedback Messages: A Three-Arm Pilot Randomized Controlled Trial
detail.abstract: BackgroundOnline psychological interventions like cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) can be provided with or without human support. Unguided online interventions require no human contact and are therefore easier to implement on a large scale than guided interventions. However, effectiveness and adherence rates to these interventions are generally lower. One way to increase adherence to unguided online interventions is to offer automated motivational support.ObjectiveThis pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) examined whether adherence to unguided online CBT for low mood could be improved by adding automated support in the form of smartphone-delivered personalized motivational messages or a motivational virtual coach integrated into the online intervention.MethodsA three-arm pilot RCT (n = 106) was conducted that compared an online intervention delivered with automated motivational support by a virtual coach (n = 35), or by automated personalized messages on their smartphone (n = 35), to the same intervention without support (control condition; n ­= 36). The primary outcome was level of adherence, operationalized as (1) the number of webpages of the intervention visited, and (2) the number of mood ratings completed on the smartphone application, both retrieved from participants’ logfiles. Secondary outcomes were satisfaction with the intervention (CSQ-I), usability (SUS) depression scores (HADS), and motivation for treatment (SMFL), measured through online questionnaires administered at baseline or after 4 weeks (post-intervention).ResultsAdherence was moderate overall, with participants visiting a range of 21 to 25 of the 55 webpages and completing 48 to 57 of the 84 mood ratings. No evidence for differences in adherence rates were observed between the intervention conditions and the control condition. Satisfaction with the intervention was moderate to high. Usability scores were below the desirable threshold of 68. Depression symptoms showed a small decrease across participants (Cohen’s d = .21), though this change was not statistically significant (p = .053). Participants across all conditions scored highest on the identified motivation subscale. ConclusionsAdding automated support to unguided online CBT for depression did not improve overall adherence. The limited effectiveness may reflect a misalignment between the motivational strategies and the needs of the target population, who reported mild symptoms and high intrinsic motivation. The findings highlight the need to further improve both the quality of automated support and the usability of online platform. Future research should explore additional adherence-related factors and investigate how personalization can better address different symptom severities in unguided mental health interventions.

detail.abstract: This study investigates the lasting human capital effects of the Nutrition Improvement Program (NIP), which provides free school meals to eligible students in rural China. Using data from the China Family Panel Studies (CFPS), we exploit the county-by-county rollout feature of the program and employ the difference-indifferences (DID) design to identify the persistent effects. The results show that early-life exposure to the NIP has beneficial effects on educational attainment and cognitive and non-cognitive skills in adulthood. The program also has sustained effects on improving emotional well-being and reducing engagement in risky health behaviors. Furthermore, the human capital benefits of the NIP are more pronounced among children from lower socioeconomic status households. This study reveals the enduring effects of school meal programs and highlights that school-based nutrition interventions should not be viewed merely as nutritional supplementation initiatives, but rather as broader human development programs.

detail.title: Early Intervention Measures and Shareholders' Rights

publicationDetails.detailsText: European Banking Institute Working Paper Series No. 192
publicationDetails.journalName: European Banking Institute (EBI) Research Paper Series

detail.abstract:
The Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive (BRRD) distinguishes between crisis prevention and crisis management measures. The former, including early intervention measures, are the responsibility of the supervisory authority, while resolution is the responsibility of the resolution authority. In outlining this distinction, the BRRD also clarifies the scope within which early intervention measures can affect shareholders' rights. It is made clear that such tools cannot dissolve corporate bodies and suspend the functioning of the shareholders' meeting. Such effects are typical of resolution as a crisis management measure.

The European Central Bank is now the competent authority for applying early intervention measures to significant banks. In this context, it is responsible for enforcing relevant EU and national legislation. However, Member States' legislation may differ from European law. One example is the Italian extraordinary administration. This procedure, which falls somewhere between early intervention measures and administrative compulsory liquidation, differs in many respects from the provisions of Article 29, BRRD. This led to a dispute over the annulment of the extraordinary administration measure adopted by the European Central Bank with regard to Banca Carige.

Against this backdrop, the paper aims to verify the compatibility of Italian legislation with European laws. It concludes that domestic law has not complied with the BRRD insofar as it has regulated a procedure that corresponds to a crisis management tool as a preventive measure. The paper also analyses the relationship between EU law and non-compliant national law, concluding that the former takes precedence in the event of a conflict.

detail.abstract: This paper examines the impact of two major family policies on maternal health, using rich claims data from the German Pharmacoepidemiological Research Database (GePaRD). We report a significant short-term impact of childcare on diagnosed respiratory diseases and heterogeneous effects on mental health. Childcare tends to reduce diagnoses of mental disorders and the use of psychotherapy among mothers with a history of mental disorders before childbirth, those with a strong attachment to the labor market and those who live in counties with low childcare provision. Conversely, low-educated mothers exhibit short-term increases in mental disorders and antidepressant use. Parental benefits alter the timing of respiratory diseases and slightly reduce mental disorders and their treatments in the first year after childbirth.

detail.abstract: This paper delves into the perceptions of urban residents in developing countries on climate change, underscoring the importance of these insights in formulating effective climate policies. As urban areas in these regions experience rapid growth and heightened vulnerability due to climate impacts, understanding local perspectives becomes crucial for both mitigating and adapting to climate change effectively. The study contributes to the body of knowledge on public perceptions of climate change, focusing particularly on the urban populations of developing countries. Despite existing literature on the subject, there remains a scarcity of research concerning cross-national variations in climate change perception within this demographic, which this paper seeks to address. To gather detailed empirical evidence, we conducted an online survey with participants from eight major cities in countries across Africa, Latin America, Southeast Asia, and South Asia. Moreover, India is becoming a major partner for many developed countries amidst the rising diplomatic conflict between the west and China. Advanced economies, including the United States, the European Union, and Japan are devising detailed strategies to strengthen relationships with India in the areas of trade, investment, development cooperation, and security. Along with these major trends, global companies in search of a huge consumer market and competitive manufacturing base are expanding investment in India. The Korean government and companies also need to strengthen their partnership with India. To support their ventures, this report takes a close look at four main areas with significant potential, namely supply chain rearrangement, digital transformation, climate change, and south-south development cooperation. The report analyses India’s position and strategy, as well as policies that Korea and India could implement to strengthen their relationship.

detail.abstract: This paper analyzes 20,640 housing blocks in 23 coastal California districts to identify socioeconomic and structural drivers of median house value. After imputing missing bedroom counts and stratifying the sample by income category, the study constructs density measures such as rooms per household and bedrooms per house. Pearson statistics show that median household income has the strongest positive association with price (ρ = 0.687). Density ratios add secondary explanatory power, whereas population size, housing age, and geographic coordinates offer limited insight once income is considered. A five hundred thousand dollar price ceiling introduces censoring at the upper tail, and strong correlations among room and population counts reveal multicollinearity. The findings indicate that income is the principal source of price dispersion along the California coast, while dwelling composition refines but does not overturn this relationship.
